name: decomposing filter bubbles - DFB
info:
## alternatively: Mapping Information Bubbles

Decomposing the filter bubble or more properly to call it decomposing my filter bubble what do I mean by this? It is the usage of something like Node-RED or a mind map or a concept map to build up a two-dimensional picture of all my thoughts and the connections between those thoughts. Instead of using a one-dimensional document to write all my thoughts down as they come, I'm now combining them all and linking them all together to see how my thoughts influence each other and what might the bigger picture be.

I find it insightful to *see* my thoughts, where they came from and how they influence each other. It presents to me a view of where my thoughts are, what do I focus on, where is my focus is dark, where is it positive, negative, social critical, love.

How does this decompose the filter bubble in which I exist?

What my diagram is implicitly showing is how the blogs, news, articles and everything else that I intellectually consuming, are influencing my thoughts. It shows how much influence a particular blog or news site has when I connect the dots or in this case, the nodes.

If I then look at the clear areas, those with little or no connection, I see the spots where I can extend and breakout of my filter bubble. Finding areas where something which I haven't discovered could be lurking in the background.

How does this work? For example putting in books that I've read, putting in the authors and then seeing what these authors also wrote and from there I see the loose ends in what I read and what I still need to read.

Visually, working with colours I also began to see missing colours, which meant I was missing references or ideas or something else to give the overall view a sense of completion. Intellectually what this is showing me is that I've not thought about something throughly enough. Perhaps I missed a contra-view, perhaps someone else has a quote that I've missed.

On the other hand, if something is to harmonious, then I say to myself where is the dissonance? 

It's linking everything together seeing flows together see how these things influence each other and then going backwards and saying okay what is the other way, what's the alternative view on that. The visualisation of that makes it easier to see these things.

Writing documents I have the fear of losing ideas to forget things and not knowing them so I write them all down but then I don't see where have I repeated myself, am I going in circles where are the new things am I new, is there something else? The unfortunate downside to one-dimensionality - the lack of connection. However in the lack of connection, one-dimensionality has it's advantage, it provides focus, it provides the room to rethink and repeat ones thoughts without being constantly being pulled back into the past.

Why stop at two-dimensionality? Why indeed! I would love to be able to do the same in three-dimensional space using VR glasses. Imagining my thoughts floating in a three dimensional space where the combine to build large, more complex thoughts and ideas. Falling apart as completely different ideas and then combing with out ideas. I virtual world of pure thought.

Why Node-RED?

==[Once again I'm going my own way there's plenty of mind maps out there and concept map tools but I'm using something which is not intended for that and that's Node Red and Node Red has different features which I do see which I require and these are the links to create links between these ideas and it's not just one directional it's bidirectional most mind maps I know are one unidirectional you go from one thought to the next to the next but you don't go looping back to things that influence each other and stuff like that so that's what I find Node Red is doing really well unfortunately Node Red has a few other issues it would be great my big idea would be to have something like a possibility of creating a larger text from thoughts so that you stream the text into a bigger document but that's the way I'm using it it's not possible which is unfortunate it'd be great if it was possible because then I could create larger text from my snippets of thoughts but that's probably version 2 then anyway so decomposing the filter bubble which is I think it's going to be a good idea it's going to be in next article something I think I might be writing about anyway ok]==


I have to admit, I started with quite a bit of source material. I am an ideas hoarder - I have an almost maniacal nature of writing all my ideas down, thankfully electronically otherwise I would be drowning in paper notes - as [Pascal](https://aeon.co/essays/aphorisms-tell-philosophys-history-as-fragments-not-systems) might well have done with his 800 slips of paper:

> When Pascal died in 1662, there were more than 800 slips of paper in various stages of disorder. These fragments are, in a large part, a direct consequence of his rejection of the Cartesian insistence on order and clarity.

I have used [iA Writer]() to give an electronic diary from which I take my snippets and bring them into my 2D world. 

Embracing repetition in form of copy and paste. In my 1D would of writing I've tried not to repeat myself or have duplication, in a 2D world I have given this hope up! I have now completely duplicated my notes into my 2D world, I change notes here and there. What is the current version? What is the best version of a thought? The answer to all those questions is simply the version I am looking at.

name: Hoarder of Ideas/Thoughts - Fear of forgetting
info:
We all have worries about all sorts of things, some good some bad. I have left all those behind until I realised that there is one worry that I constantly carry around with me and that is the worry that I will forget something. This is subtle that it becomes nearly impossible to realise. Recently I came to understand that some thoughts, when I write them down, actually aren't yet finished. So I have developed the notion of meditating a little longer before writing down my thoughts. In fact I have come to the point where I write summaries of those thoughts that remain after a meditation session - all the thoughts that remain are either completed, or still open-ended or rememberable/memorable. hang on, that list includes all thoughts right? well no, it doesn't include those thoughts that have been forgotten! and that's the point, when I get the urge to write something down, I breath in and let the thoughts ramble just that little bit longer. Thus I am going against my worry of forgetting a thought but only in doing so can I have longer and deeper thoughts.

Thoughts are like chemicals in a 3D sphere drifting around. They combine to build longer chain of thoughts and sometimes they go apart again and combine into other chains of thought. They overlap and cross each other to build complex ideas. Preventing or mitigating this process too soon can be prevent the formation of longer more beautiful thoughts.

name: Electricity will be the oil crisises of the 21st century
info:
Just as the oil crisis shocked the western world, so will an electricity crisis.

It might not happen as bad as all that since electricity is global, thanks to the sun. So this crisis might well be completely different but it will come.

What will happen? As society moves to an electricity based economy - electric cars, electric phones, electric pumps to transfer warmth in the winter, electric everything, electricity takes centerpoint of society, much as oil did for much of the 20th century.

We believe as a society that we have learnt from the mistakes of the past and move to electricity to replace oil. Unfortunately we are moving to a far more fragile society since electricity isn't something that comes out of the ground and can be used. Electricity is an end product of a chain of activity. Either via conversion from oil, or conversion from sunlight or conversion of wind.

Electricity loses much in transport so that it becomes a very local product, depdended on the current conditions being faced on a local level. Norway produces a lot of electricity via dams and water energy. That is a local product that is depended on the water supply.

Those that burn coal to produce electricity are depended on that coal, etc.

So the crisis won't be the Saudias not selling us oil, rather it will be that local conditions do not provide enough electricity and the our electrical-based economy will come to a halt. This local problem expands as the neighbours around one are asked to provide electricity. But as transport of electricity is a major problem still, this will cause more problems. Local areas will be left to fend for themselves.

A further issue with electricity is that it can be influenced by sunflares. These can easily destroy the electrical infrastructure that we have created.

name: How to use Node-RED as Mind-map - shortcuts
info:
To make this happens, need to make it clear how to use the shortcuts that I use and how I make the whole thing work well for me:

- using search to navigate around my map (**cmd-F**) also using the 'type:XXX' search filter

- using **cmd-uparrow** and cmd-downarrow to move nodes to align them along straight joins

- how i organise my stuff with **links-in and links-out** and give some guidelines for naming those links

- **cmd-D** for deploying, i.e. saving the map. which could perhaps be done between with an automatic process such penpot uses.

- using search to find links in/out in the sidebar for creating a link. **Naming convention** for links in/out (i.e. the same as the node they represent)

- **cmd-0/-/+** to zero and reset zoom, great for quickly getting an overview of an entire mind map

- **shift-click** to highlight all nodes in an immediate cluster of connected nodes.

- **shift-enter** to close and save the editor sidebar. It then becomes a matter of shift-enter, cmd-d to update content.

- **alt-a** for alignment to make things look good:

```
⌥-a l - left align
⌥-a c - center align
⌥-a r - right align

⌥-a t - top align
⌥-a m - middle align
⌥-a b - bottom align
```

name: Use Zoom level to create a third dimension
info:
Each zoom level has its own collection of nodes that can be connected to nodes below it.

Basically as you zoom out, you can add nodes but that are "normal" size. These can be connected to all visible nodes, be they the same size as the node just added or a smaller node (a node that is on a zoom level below the current level).

All nodes on higher zoom levels (or lower depending on your perspective) would not be visible - in fact you might only have maximum two levels of zoom visible at all times.

But there would be connections (just as the link in/out have) links indicating that there are more connections into other zoom levels.

(there seem to be 10 zoom levels from default zoom level, so probably 5 levels in either direction would be fine, i.e. every second zoom step generates a new layer of nodes)

name: mining the mind
info:
## Mining my mind

I imagine a coal face a pickaxe in one hand and a lantern in the other. I begin to chip away, burrowing my way into the coal face. Chip for chip I get further into the mountain.

I imagine the shafts as I pickaxe my way through my mind, thrust by thrust, word by word my texts are created. Each shaft is slowly perfected and supported by beams of grammar and supports of elegancy.

So it is, as I chip away at my stories. With my pen I chip away the words in my mind, word for word, extending the shaft. Stabilising the shaft with beams of grammar, supports of learning. 

As the shafts get longer and more intertwined, the more complex they get. Sometimes they collapse and a new shaft needs to be dug. Always following a vein of inspiration, wherever that may take me.

Sometimes shafts are given up as having been mined, not being of the perfect structure required for the text. No amount of reshaping would bring them back into alignment with the text. They are abandoned, to perhaps be rediscovered by another mine of my mind.

I burrow deeper and deeper into my unconscious, being amazed by the intricate structure I discover. Sometimes fossils of bygone stories appear. They now seem to make sense in this new mine.

Each text becomes its own mine into my mind. Occasionally minefields appear that undermine my mining of mine mind, regardless I progress further. 

Sometimes I end up coming up for air. Light blending my eyes and I begin to reflect. Reflect on what it is that I have discovered in my mind, reflect on what I have constructed and reflect upon the unconscious that brought me here.

Plans of the mine of mine mind show me the complexity that I have woven together to make a story that appeals, when only, to me but that is my mine of my mind. 

Extracting the gold dust of my mind to weave the intricate stories of my mind. 



---

This imaginary is quite different to the usual reason for a mine: extraction. In this case the text is being shaped and designed by the shafts of the mind. Or the text is shaped with the mine while the words are mined from the mind.

name: fidgetious
info: Yesterday and today had the feeling of being over distracted from todos that all wanted doing. I get this when too many ideas begin to pop up in my head and I can't get rid of them. **Each idea is a like a little child screaming for the attention of its parent.** A birds nest of beaks all at the same time screaming for food and attention. My usual switching between tasks becomes a hectic, distracted, confused approach. Beginning with one todo, then get distracted by another todo, switching to that todo only to be distracted by the original task until I'm totally confused as to what I should be doing. Perhaps the best thing is to write about this. An alternative that I find works quite well is to grab a *good* book and lie on the sofa for an hour. That calms the soul and steadies the mind. But mind you, if it's not a good book, I'll be up and about within five minutes. That's why I've always have to have a good book to hand. Another approach is to write down ideas to forget them or rather have them out of my mind. Have a note book handy to write those ideas down, short quick sentences or just a few chosen words. But that sometimes doesn't work. In some situations the todos and ideas need doing and I would like to do each one but, for the life of me, I don't know in which order I should approach them. In some cases I think about the order - quickest first or the least difficult or the task-upon-which-all-tasks-depend first - but at times when the mind is fidgetious (from fidgety + continuously), it feels as if the mind doesn't have the necessary calmness to find an ordering. The mind becomes a hyper-spiral of hyper-activity resulting in deadlock and gridlock. In such state, it is also impossible to perform any task to any level of competence - that is to say, picking a task to do leads to being distracted so I can't concentrate on that task, so I end up performing it badly. What's the point of doing that? That's way taking a break on the sofa can really help to calm the mind and focus the spirit.

name: Seeing the path out of the labyrinith of the mind
Rethinking Mindmaps in the age of Artifical Intelligence
info:
Download file

So, rethinking mind maps in the age of AI. So creating a mind map nowadays in the age of AI, AI being a representation of our mind in form of a computer, in form of silicon, that representation is how we believe the mind works like. And mind maps are apparently a map of our minds. Now, it's the classical mind maps go, they have square boxes that go out with lines going out and out and out, and there's no looping back and there's no typing. So these boxes don't have really much type. And there's no, there's no interaction with a mind map, it's created, and then you look at it and go, well, and all these things are old school mind maps. So let's try and recreate those mind maps, let's make them interactive. Since this is a very important thing, since we want a interaction between our minds and ourselves because our minds don't stand still. It's not like that. We can create a snapshot of our minds. But since we've created that snapshot, it's actually antiquated and pointless. So we need to keep on maintaining our mind maps and maintain them in a simple and easy way to do that, to update them as our thoughts gradually grow and then expand. And also our minds are interactive, I interact with my mind, I think, and I interact and I have thoughts and I build concepts and I build ideas. And this is the same way that a mind map should be, it should be interactive and computational. So based on my mind map, I want to create new ideas, new thoughts. So I want to be able to go through my mind and building up new ideas. So it has to be interactive. And a mind map should also provide types. I have an idea, I have a thought, I have an observation, I have a question. These are different types of thoughts I maintain in my mind map. So I need to be able to type mind maps. Mind maps should be working like science. I have certain inputs, from those inputs I create certain thoughts, and from those thoughts, from multiple thoughts, I create conclusions and theories. Or other way around, I have a conclusion and a theory, and I would recreate the thoughts and the ideas and the experiments to prove that theory. So that's another way a mind map should be able to be used and worked. And this all adds up to a type of mind map where one has a bi-directional linking between nodes, one can alter the types of nodes, one can interact with the types of nodes, one interacts with the nodes of the mind map. One has media, one has a mind contains songs, contains videos, contains images, contains situations. So a mind map must also contain videos and audio and pictures, because that's what our minds also have. And should be able to interlink minds. My mind is interlinked with the minds of my friends. So we share parts of our minds together. So that's the way mind maps should also be interlinkable. And we have also different types, including also people. So you need to have nodes that represent people in your mind map. You have to represent all these concepts that we have in the world within a mind map. And that can be interlinked, all types, everything can be interlinked, even though it might seem silly to be interlinking a video with an observation, but that's the way our mind works. And I have an observation, I have a thought, I have an experiment, and I have a video to that because that's something particularly happened, something, a scenario happened, and that caused me to have that thought. That has to be interlinked. So that's the future of mind maps, make intelligent mind maps this way. And if these mind maps grow big enough, then we can probably create intelligence out of that, you can create pathways of thoughts. And so in a certain sense, you move up the chain of intelligence. And instead of predicting words, AI will predict pathways through mind maps. Okay, so you tokenize the prompts, and you create pathways, and then you simulate these pathways within various mind maps, and then you predict the next node that would come up on this mind map. And so then you're actually handling concepts and not words, and nodes and not words. So that will make it an artificial intelligence, far more intelligence than just predicting words without any particular context. And since you're also dividing, you create pathways within mind maps, you can easily say, okay, this is the pathway that actually created this answer or this node. So you can also have, you have context, and you have referential ability, you reference, you take a reference of what pathway you're using. And you have [nachvollziehbarkeit](https://www.dict.cc/?s=Nachvollziehbarkeit) [Ed: traceability, replicability, transparency]. So basically, you can understand what is happening and why it happened.

name: profound boredom
info:
"profound boredom"

profound boredom is the boredom one suffers when solitude and loneliness are approach, at home alone, with nothing to do and no one to talk to. according to this [article](https://www.bath.ac.uk/announcements/social-media-may-prevent-users-from-reaping-creative-rewards-of-profound-boredom-new-research/) and the corresponding [hacker news](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=34138188) discussion, this can lead to creative phases where new ideas can finally take form.

The original paper differentiates between superficial boredom - the kind experienced at a bus stop waiting for a bus and the profound boredom whereby your are alone at home with nothing to do.

From a [comment](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=34141244) there could also be a form of *attentive* boredom whereby you are stuck in a traffic jam, completely boredom but you have to remain attentive to prevent accidents. That kind of boredom could be the worst form since you can't do anything that takes your attention but on the other hand, your attention is tired to a very boring activity.

I put in a [comment](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=34142148) about *What exactly is the difference between idling, daydreaming, meditating, musing or sitting on sofa with eyes shut and profound boredom?* The deeper meaning here is that there are many ways to activate creativity or give the brain a pause, something that our brains need just as our bodies: *Aren't all these activities doing the same thing, giving the brain pause to calm down, to refocus. Perhaps our brains require idle times as our bodies need pause after exercise.* as the comments continues.

There are some who seem to [worry that they kids should not be bored](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=34141173). If true, it is strange to believe that ensuring that your children are never bored would prepare them for life. Working life is mostly about being bored and if you can't handle it or recognise it, then you will have a fairly frustrating life.

The HN discussion really hit home for me. I spend a lot of time being "bored" but not because I don't have anything to do nor not because I don't have any ideas, but because my mind needs a rest. A rest from the constant input of the sensory world. I'm spending more and more time meditating, which for me is a form of controlled boredom. In fact meditating is the challenge to accept and experience boredom for long periods of time. So in a sense, I force boredom onto myself because sometimes I get the nervous feeling that everything is too much and I am about to explode.

I have come to realise that meditation, for me, is about shutting off the sensors. Shut eyes, quiet room or constant, relaxing music, no taste, no touching and no smell. The entire situation of classic meditation is deconstruction of sensoria input. Only by preventing the mind from being activated by input can the mind come to rest and settle down for a moment. And it only has to be for a moment. Boredom is for me a state of involuntary meditation then. One can only reach profound boredom by having no sensory inputs.

It would also be interesting to know whether boredom has become a luxury item. Can people afford to be profoundly bored, not superficial bored in a world where time is money and everyone is running around trying to make a buck or two.

It was ironic that I found the article and the HN discussion in a moment of boredom, it's discovery made my boredom strangely productive. In addition to that, it made be creative and write this text.

name: Blogroller
info:
As to be found at blog.openmindmap.org - a blogging software based on the writermap nodes.

The worlds first blog based on a mind-map diagram with live updates.

**Personally Philosophically Reflecting on Node-RED**

Perhaps I should quickly point what my motivation is in doing this. 

I began using Node-RED as a programming environment for doing *stuff* and soon realised that the two-dimensionality of Node-RED provided one more dimension than my editor. I began also seeing the flexibility Node-RED provided and began more and more to think about the representation of a node.

Node-RED node makes the assumption that nodes are bits of computer code that get executed and passed along connections. I saw colourful boxes that were joined to one another! I saw these boxes as representing anything, not just code to be executed.

I began using nodes as content, content of my writings. I realised that the one-dimensionality of my editor was limiting my ideas and writing. What was at the top of a document was never seen again. What was written days ago, was forgotten and repeated in long documents.

I needed to organise my writing in a better form. That is when I began viewing Node-RED as a mind-map tool, but a mind-map tool with executable nodes. So I began wondering what my mind-map nodes should be doing when they get executed.

And that's when I came up with the idea of have my mind-maps generate texts for me.

Ironically this is proving to be difficult since I am moving for two-dimensions to one-dimension and that implies that I lose a dimension. Gaining a dimension means more freedom, reducing means culling that freedom.

I am beginning to think that a blog, i.e., a one-deminsional web representation, is not the perfect means to transport content in mind-map form.

And that is still part of the experiment: how to find a better way to provide motivation for creating your own mind-map and uploading to openmindmap.org (one day) to create a global mind map.

name: SubPass option on nodes / Summary Node
info:
A options to specify that a writermap node is a summary node collecting all the details of other nodes together and passing this into a into a node.


![img](https://cdn.openmindmap.org/content/1687853303094_Screen_Shot_2023-06-27_at_10.08.03.png)

In this case the `SubPassNode` would have a checkbox to activate the summarisation (this would be shown in the label with an ∑ sum symbol). The checkbox would activate a dropdown to select the output node to which the summary shoud be passed (its passed to all connected nodes but this node isn't part of the summary).

The `Thought` node would get a writermap array with an entry for the subpass node that contained it's sub-nodes, so the hash would have an extra array containing the details of the subnodes conencted to the `SubPassNode`.

The result returned by the SubPassNode would be passed to all its connected output nodes however it is assumed that the subnodes aren't connected on - i.e. they really only provide a point in a list or arguments collection or whatever.

Any writernode can be made to a subpass node, this isn't a special extra node. Hence the checkbox and the dropdown list for selecting the output node to which the data is sent.

(SubPass or SumPass is from summaries and pass on or sub-nodes passed on)

name: less is more
info:
## less is more

Most important when describing a scene, you don't need much in the way of description. This is something I notice when I was reading [Vonnegut](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurt_Vonnegut) - he has very lovely pictures in his books but his descriptions can be limited so that the imagine of the reader does the rest. The rule of thumb is that common things that must people have a understanding of or have experience need minimal description: "a house was standing on the hill, its two front windows where ablaze with the light from within" from the reader can make their own picture. Alternative would be "a white-coloured house having two front windows stood on the hill. the windows where framed in wooden frames made of the old mahogany that the trees around the house gave up willingly. the the windows were ablaze with the lights from within". The latter might just too much for the average reader unless it is of relevance that there are mahogany trees growing around the house. I think that Vonnegut does this well, for example in [sirens of titan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sirens_of_Titan) he describes the house of Rumfoord on titan as being a copy of the taj malhal. Done. there isn't any further description because it is not relevant for the plot and secondly reader is assumed to know what the taj malhal looks like. Instead Vonnegut describes the lakes and rivers that are located on titan, i.e. the things the reader has no imagery of. And that's important: to provide readers with imagery and description that they have not encountered.

name: Empathy
info:
https://millieons.org/w/empathy

It was raining on my head but it wasn't the rain from clouds, it was the rain of a shower head cleansing me. It is in these moments of silent reflection that thoughts come to me. Most probably these thoughts come from somewhere deep in my subconscious. These are the moments when the conscious is blackened by the motoric that takes over during tasks that are completely automatic. Feelings of warmth, relaxation and safety reinforce this state.

Today was a day were I was reflecting on life and dealing with family affairs. I was particularly emotional triggered in a melancholy feeling of oneness with the universe. It was at the moment reflecting on empathy and the ability to be empathic.

My mother was a particularly empathic person, caring for many people in her life, not least her four children. I was wondering why we as children weren't particularly empathic people. In fact being quite the opposite, very focussed on ourselves and our problems. Far too busy with thoughts of our own dire straits to be bother with other people and their problems.

I wondered why this would be the case. Having a very loving and caring mother who rarely, if ever, desired to be the middle point of any event or situation. I realised that to be an empathic person you need to have experienced the joy of caring for others. To put yourself at the disposal of someone in need. To push your worries and problems to the outside and listen to other peoples troubles. All these activities have to be actively experienced to understand and comprehend the joys of empathy.

Empathy is a not a science that you can learn from a textbook, there aren't any hard and fast rules on how to be empathic to other people. And it was this realisation that made me think about us children.

Having experienced empathy on a daily basis did not make us empathic. Instead we assumed that empathy would always be there for us. There would always be someone looking after us and we won't need to provide support to others.

Becoming adults the world changed from a very empathetic, loving world to a taking, wanting, greedy, cruel world. And perhaps we were lost in this world. Lost perhaps because our emotional needs weren't being fulfilled. Lost because we always needed our mother for the empathy we had as children.

And now with the passing away of our mother, we are completely lost. Our only source of empathy has evaporated.

The well is dry and we search for a new well.

name: Empathy
info:
Empathy is a manifestation of altruism, or is it the other way around? Both take the centre point of ones life - oneself - and moves this centre point to the external world around oneself. Focusing on other people, other problems and other joys. Being able to be happy for someone else, accepting and enjoying someones victory over oneself. Sharing that joy is true altruism. Being big enough to jump over ones own shadow. The leopard that does change its spots.

Empathy is an active action of altruism. It is the letting-someone-else-win action for the sack of the greater good. It is the action of helping someone to the point of detrimental consequences for oneself. The highest form is throwing yourself in front of the proverbial bus to save someone else. You die, they survive.

What form does empathy take? There is the **emotional empathy**, probably the most common form. It's the feeling and understanding of emotions that another person has. It's the conversational sharing that happens amongst good friends. It's the listening to other peoples pains and joys without interruption or discourse, simply listening and understanding.

There is the financial empathy of giving someone less well-of than yourself financial support. Be it that beggar on the street or a friend who has lost all their money on the horses and cannot pay their rent. **Financial empathy** is probably the easiest form of empathy to measure, but the hardest form to execute. I loaned you this much money and no I don't want it back .... or do I? That is the execution, overcoming that doubt and realisation that some of your own financial freedom has been sacrificed to support someone else. And financial freedom is freedom in a capitalistic society that is the West.

**Physical empathy** is giving someone a hug when they need it. Providing that human closeness that we all need. The only thing that needs to be conquered is ones own physical repulsion of the other person. When was that last time you gave that beggar a hug? Physical empathy can do a lot of good, more good than other forms of empathy however it is probably the shortest lived form of empathy. It's the shot of cocaine that disappears about as fast it's gone up the nose.

**Intellectual empathy** is the ability to accept someones view on a particular matter that is for oneself very clear and obvious but complete opposed to the view the other. To accept that and not criticise their standpoint is a form of intellectual empathy. It is the acceptance that the world is flat, potential causing a cognitive dissonance in ones own mind. It is the acceptance that nothing will convince the other of their intellectual failings which is the highest art. It is the renunciation of all forms of debate to argue the point that makes one grow and love more. In that this growing one wins the personal joy of empathy.

And it is the personal joy of helping someone that makes empathy an addictive feeling. It is the purity of this feeling that makes the difference between empathy that is altruist and empathy that is egoist. The empathy that arises from have a bad conscience and thinking that helping someone will clear that conscience that is the empathy based on the ego.

Giving someone money because one is having an affair with that persons partner is a form of empathy that is based on the submission to a bad conscience rather than the pure joy of giving. Unless of course one has told that person one is having an affair with that persons partner!

Giving based on taking isn't empathy.

Taking here takes many forms. Emotional taking, physical taking, and so on, are indirecting taking that might motivate direct giving. Is it bad to give in response to taking? Well no, not per se. It's just not showing empathy and therefore it should be sold as being empathy.

_Giving based on taking is a transaction._

A quid pro quo so to say. So what could the motivation behind empathy be? Why do some people literally help others to their own detriment? Probably the answer to this is similar to finding the one unifying theory of physics, wake me when we've found it. In fact there are probably just as many answers as there are people being empathetic.

One form that I've discovered is a very personal form that I inherited from my mother. It's the empathy based on the joy of making random strangers happy. Making something beautiful and the placing it somewhere, not waiting for its discovery nor the joy that it (hopefully) brings when discovered. It is the thought of the joy makes me happy and is my personal motivation to continue.

My mother imparted this onto me in a very subtle form. It took many years for me to understand and act on this form of empathy but it happened quite naturally. It is the empathy that happens when oneself is under enormous stress and burden. It is going against the ‌automatism of feeling bad and lonely in bad times, it is taking the reverse position and doing something positive which makes oneself feel positive. It fact is taking the negative energy and combining it all to get a positiveness - two negatives make a positive. This also works for emotional energies.

name: Shared Pain is halved pain, shared love is doubled.
info:
It was a wet and stormy night that found me sitting at the bar at one of my favourite bars. As I usual do on nights like these and many other nights that aren't as wet and stormy. Believing that to be a good writer, you need to be a good drinker.

I talk to strangers, friends and lovers. Listening to their stories, reflecting on mine and enjoying the meditation that can only come while staring at my drink. Being a writer can be a lonely business and having at least some social contact with real people does me good.

Having an office job provides a zoo of social interactions. People are everywhere, meetings are constant and thoughts are buried amongst the discussions about coffee and where to eat lunch.

Office jobs are predestinated to shutting one away from empathy, weakening the strength to listen, really listen and not drift off in thoughts that, for me in that moment, seem more relevant than someones problems with their work. Discussions that seem to go on in ever growing spirals, grinding away the spirit of interacting and being honest with people.

When I did have an office job, my only desire in the evenings was to reenter the space of silence that was my apartment. My head was filled with work, the issues that plagued my day and the minor incidents that would drive people to their emotional wit's ends. It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.

It is the empathy found in sharing pain that drives me to these evenings in bars. Listening to people who are being open and honest about their lives, their challenges and their dreams. Those characteristics that make us all human yet that we believe we suffer through alone.

My essential needs for ideas and thoughts is what drives me to these evenings of random interactions with beings that have the same problems just in different colours. The green of jealous, the red of anger, the blue of tranquility and the white radiate light of enlightenment when my own problems melt away in the face of dire straits of other peoples helplessness.

And it is this bonus of giving empathy and winning the enlightenment that my problems are ...minor... and insignificant that makes me want to listen. Eagerly recognising the failings of my concerns.

Yet all these nights are gone now.

This book is a persiflage on Ayn Rands works and philosophy. *Wow, it's a fountain pen* is a reference to her book *The Fountainhead* and the subtitle *In praise of altruism* is taken from her work [*The virtue of Selfishness*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Virtue_of_Selfishness). I personal have issues with Ayn Rands philosophy of [*Objectivism*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objectivist_movement) which aims to place the self front and centre of all existence. In her words: > My philosophy, in essence, is the concept of man as a heroic being, with his own happiness as the moral purpose of his life, with productive achievement as his noblest activity, and reason as his only absolute. My addition to that would be: *to the detriment of all others* - see [*The virtue of Selfishness*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Virtue_of_Selfishness). It is this detriment to all others that I dislike. The simple fact is: no person can achieve their own personal happiness *without* influencing their surroundings, their environment, their fellow beings. The following sums it up for me: > No ones personal happiness consists of working for a large corporation delivering products made by other large corporations to people working for yet other large corporations, hoping to find their personal happiness in those products. Ayn Rand died a rational, lonely person who never allowed emotions to get in the way of rationality. Luckily with her [*the world did not end*](https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/309519-i-will-not-die-it-s-the-world-that-will-end), instead it was only her world that ended. On the other hand Ayn Rand and I are not that far apart after all, everyone should seek their personal happiness but *not* to the detriment of others, instead in an *altruist* manner of seeking ones own happiness in the happiness of others. This then becomes a dystopian science fiction tale as the thought of *altruistically* helping others is dystopian to those who solely believe in themselves. I use of the pronoun 'He' throughout this book, the author happens to be male, the book is an incompletely autobiography hence 'I' would be inappropriate. The author does not to wish to offend anyone, as a small recompense, a poem: > I her he
> You me we
> Them they us
> Aren't we all just
> Astronauts on Spaceship Earth? This being a hat tip to [Richard Buckminster Fuller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buckminster_Fuller) who popularised the term *Spaceship Earth*. He did coin the term [*Ephemeralization*](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ephemeralization&oldid=1114035411) which can be taken to mean: > [...] the ability of technological advancement to do "more and more with less and less until eventually you can do everything with nothing," [...] Which appears to be coming reality except we humans will not be needed as humans require a lot more than *nothing* to get through life.

name: Untrodden paths
info:
Always take the least trodden path or make your own fresh path through life. This helps you to avoid all the others that have taken the common path. If you take the well trodden path, you will come out there were either everyone is or has been.

This can be a lonely journey through life, one that requires trust and belief in oneself. To be assured that one is making the right choices, there are no signposts or waypoints to know you are on the right path. There are no fellow travellers on your path.

Trust in yourself is the only guide on a journey through the virginal landscape of your life. Believing and knowing that you are making the right choices along the path is the guiding star in the night sky.

Occasionally one stumbles upon fellow travellers, either they have been there were before one arrives or they have been waiting for you to arrive. It is up to oneself to hold those travellers in esteem as guides providing assurance or as a monument to failure, one has come to somewhere, be it an idea or a thought, that someone else has previously thought. Ones path has brought one to the point where someone else was but coming via a different route.

It was the latter aspect that had escaped me for a long time. I have travelled along the untrodden, unspoiled paths of life, coming to regions unbeknownst to the many. Many a time I would come across a piece wisdom that would confirm something I had thought or created. That someone else could have thought the same that I had would always cause a sense of failure in me as it made me feel as if I had been walking in circles. I always wished to travel the untouched landscapes, to be the explorer that finds the lost continent.

A recent piece of wisdom that made me see the light was Carl Jung when he wrote:

> Until you make the unconscious conscious, it will rule your life and you will call it Fate.

==I have come to the point of [...]==

Initial it made me feel as if my ideas on letting the unconscious guide me were not novel or innovative, they were a *rediscovery* of Jung. This made me a little sad.

Then I realised that no, this was a good sign. It showed that, in my own way, I got to where Jung already was. This means that I understand what Jung had to say and it's taken my path and experiences to understand him. No teacher, no lecturer could have done the same as me finding and honouring Jung on my own.

And that when I realised that *rediscovery* is sometimes *invention* for oneself:

On a planet where America has already been discovered, no one else will the discovery of America. In a world where everything has been invented, discovery is sometimes just as good as invention - for oneself.

Further examples:

- Brecht with his creativity under pressure of from the Nazis - this is a clear copy of what wrote about my mother and her ability to be positive under massive amounts of stress.
- Nietzsche and his acclaim of Buddhism as an alternative to the christian church, which concise with my finding Buddhism through meditation 
- Adam Curtis and his [interview](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lp2vGAD-BGw) where he says at the end that societies narrow their range of thoughts down so as not to jump out of the mainstream river, and this is compares to my criticism of the christian church that implants thoughts and ideas into our heads that prevent us from thinking of better alternatives.
- Huxley and his doors of perception which I read and never understood and then suddenly came clarity which is also a point for that sometimes wisdom only comes with experience and that certain pieces of knowledge only make sense if you have the right experiences.
Just another unpleasant piece of evidence that the world does not revolve around you
Make the unconscious conscious, else you will be guided by it and call it fate.

name: Influencing the Unconscious
info:
*Working with the unconscious is similar to having a baby: it arrives when it wants, it screams, eats, shits on its own timetable and we love it for being our shared future generation.* -- Me.

This would be the rational, scientific, accepted interpretation of the unconscious which is also reflected in the nominal notion of unconscious as being the *subconscious*: a *sub* or degraded form of the consciousness.

For society complexity blocks simplicity, that which is not complex cannot work, so simple approaches for a better humanity are ignored or dismissed. 

1) Pick up a glass of water and drink from it. Now reflect on how that happened. First your conscious formulated the desire for water. Then the conscious decided to drink from that glass. How did the water get into your mouth and stomach? How did your body prevent the water from going into your lungs? How did the glass end up on the counter from which you original picked up from? All these actions were coordinated, carried-out and controlled by your unconscious. You could even continue listening to whoever it was that was talking to you as you drank from the glass. It was the unconscious that controlled all the muscles and nerves that made it happen and that is an incredible performance for something that is occasionally, degraded to being "sub"-par to our conscious.

2) Typing on a keyboard is not a matter of coordinating muscles to tap keys on a keyboard, it is a matter of formulating sentences and ideas so that our unconscious can interact with the keyboard to create those sentences.

3) Reflex, gut feelings, emotions, instinct, muscle memory are all based in the unconscious. These are those unexplained actions that we sometimes revert to when we just react without reflection. *Consciously* catching a ball in flight would require immeasurable amount of calculus to compute the flight path to know when and where our hands should go to catch the ball. Alternatively we let our unconscious do all the work and we *instinctively* catch the ball.

Of course there are numerous other examples of how the unconscious assists us through our lives. Just imagine getting out of bed in the mornings if each muscle would need to be actively coordinated. When was the last time you actively beat your heart or reminded yourself to take a breath of air?

That is why we talk of muscle memory: those activities that one never forgets how to perform. Everything from bicycle riding to typing on a keyboard, to peeling a potato. Unfortunately it has nothing to with the muscle memory (or do muscles have memory cells?), it is the unconscious which has learnt to perform these tasks.

Once we realise how powerful the unconscious really is, how can we use it? Anyone who has forgotten a name only to remember it some time later when the name just pops into ones head knows that the unconscious can be used somewhat as an instrument of query.

For anyone who has played competitive sport, being relaxed, being focussed and in the zone are all possibilities to allow the unconscious to help them reach their best performance. The point of practice is not to develop the "muscle memory" but to train the unconscious to perform the task at the highest level of accuracy.

Why do we have our best ideas under the shower in the morning? We enter a kind of comfortable automatic mode whereby the conscious is tuned out and the subconscious is guiding the show. Having time to allow that to happen is very important if you want to make the most of what your mind has to offer. Give your unconscious the time to reflect and then listen to its suggestions. Just as you "command" the unconscious to drink from a glass of water, so too can you ask the unconscious to provide that name that you have forgotten.

Just as that name pops in your head, so too do possible solutions to those issues that having constantly going through your head. If you do not listen to those suggestions, then you are only using twenty percent of your possibilities. As the unconscious is very shy, you need to provide it with space to speak with you. Conscious is a stage hogger and loves the limelight, getting conscious to be backstage can help to have the unconscious come into the limelight.

But moving on, I hope I was able to point out the importance of the unconscious and its comparability with the conscious, if not its exaltation of the latter. I come now to the point of this article: how to influence the unconscious? Not how to dominate the unconscious, instead how to provide guidance. To guide the unconscious in spontaneous situations were we react, so that we react in a ways that sit comfortably with our conscious beliefs.

When spontaneously catching falling objects off a kitchen bench, we catch the glass but avoid the knife. This is the guidance that our unconscious has learned. How can we guide our unconscious to react with love and not hate? The falling knife is left to fall out of a love to ourselves rather than a fear of injury. But this is a love for ourselves and not a love of others, how to teach the unconscious to react in love to others and not just in love to ourselves?

How then can the unconscious be influenced? Humans have two very powerful emotions happiness and fear. Fear is the basis for hate, jealousy, being scared, and assorted other negative emotions. Happiness, oneness with provides the basis for love, sharing, caring and the positive emotions that make life worthwhile. Both can influence the unconscious, of course, in opposite directions.

Of the two, fear is the more motivational. Humans go to war on the basis of fear, fear of those we think are threatening us. A fear of missing out makes us use applications that make us feel miserable about ourselves. Advertising uses fear to make you think that you are not good enough unless you purchase a specific product.

Happiness allows us to come together and enjoy life together. Happiness allows us to live together without fearing something will happen.

Influencing the unconscious becomes a question of reaching the unconscious.

His belief was that the computer, at its most base level, is a fundamentally conservative force and that despite being a technological innovation, it would end up hindering social progress. name: consciousness is a memory
info:
An article on the [conscious](https://singularityhub.com/2022/10/25/could-consciousness-be-a-memory-system-new-theory-says-yes/):

> It gets more mind-bending. Rather than perceiving the world in real time, we’re actually experiencing a memory of that perception. That is, our unconscious minds filter and process the world under the hood, and often make split-second decisions. When we become aware of those perceptions and decisions—that is, once they’ve risen to the level of consciousness—we’re actually experiencing “memories of those unconscious decisions and actions,” the authors explained.

How does conscious awareness develop?

The original article, if true, would imply that memory came before conscious experience. I would assume that unconscious instincts/reflexes/emotions where the original experience of all species. Is it instinct that does not work without a memory? Instinct to know that a lion will eat us if we get close?

I would assume that consciousness did not develop in parallel to unconsciousness. This I consider can be seen in the development of a baby to an adult, we can't recall our earliest moments of birth (regardless of how go our memories our). This for me demonstrates that our conscious is not mature at birth, it is honed over the first few months of childhood.

Conscious developing out of the memories that we collect makes complete sense if we consider that a babys' conscious develops as it grows. This then would be because new born babies don't have any memories. As the unconscious fills the memory banks of the mind, our conscious becomes ever more present.

Where did conscious come from?

Dreams could hold the key to the development of the conscious. Other species dream, one can observe a dog twitching its legs and eyes as it sleeps. Psychologist claim that one reason we dream is that we are storing away the events of the day. Thus in our dreams we fill the memory banks of the mind.

I would argue that the spark for our conscious came through our dreaming. The visual effects that we call dreams is the feedback into our visual cortex as our minds store away events of the day. This is how our instinct is honed over the years. Each snake, lion or spider becomes a further entry in our library of animals that might cause us harm.

The waking process of having those dream images in ones head could have been the point at which we questioned the world. Slowly awaking with imagery that did not reflect what had happened or which reflected an enemy yet faced, might well have triggered a change in the mind to allow the experiencer to reflect on those imagery. And with this reflection came consciousness.

If one goes a step further and reflects on psychedelic drugs, which a tribe of hunter and gathers would have gotten in contact with, that experience would have triggered imagery that would have triggered questioning, finally with that questioning came the consciousness.

How to use the Unconscious?

[Carl Jung](https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/44379-until-you-make-the-unconscious-conscious-it-will-direct-your) summed it up:

> Until you make the unconscious conscious, it will direct your life and you will call it fate.

The subtlety in what Jung says is that we can consciously use the unconscious to live our lives or be unconsciously guided by fate, which is happening today. Transforming the unconscious from being passive to being active.

[...]

How to plan?

For me the conclusion is that planning lies in desire: I desire something, allow my unconscious to guide me and I will get what I desire. I give the unconscious a command and it will ensure that command is fulfilled. This does not only include immediate things such as drinking a coffee or moving an object. It means long term goals and long term plans. Fulfilling plans becomes a case of giving the unconscious as many opportunities and possibilities to guide us, to guide us to the our long term goal or to fulfil our plans.

This requires trust and faith in the unconscious. The faith of knowing the unconscious wishes to help us and the trust that the unconscious recognises and knows the path to our goal. And this is a big ask for a society that is conscious-based society, one driven by "conscious decision making". In not regarding the unconscious as part of us, we end up making stories to fill in the gaps of our misunderstanding of why we make certain decisions instead of accepting them and trusting that they lead us in the right direction.

What about Oneness?

[...]

Need to realise that true oneness is reached when the distinction between conscious and unconscious has been dissolved. this does not mean death, this means in thinking. the emphasis on unconscious and conscious can bring one to a certain point but beyond that point, one has to embrace oneness. embracing oneness means oneness in mind without question.

In the realisation that true oneness is found by dissolving the divide between conscious and unconscious, comes the perplexing conflict of letting go of something I had recently discovered. I had to let go of my understand of the depth and vastness and guidance of the unconscious for me to spiritually move on. Again I saw the delegate wisdom of the Buddha, journey and letting go. Letting go of my mother, letting go of my unconscious guidance, lets me go and move on spiritually, to reach a oneness with true peace and harmony.

It becomes uncomfortable when one begins to think about what comes after Oneness? The answer lies within the universe. Oneness carries in it the seeds of the Big Bang, a spiritual new start which will lead to the Oneness of spirit, the eternal circle of spirituality. Rediscovery is invention in a world that has forgotten all.

name: Living by the Fibonacci numbers
info:
The idea came while having a discussion with Tim (no details known) who works for a company that models plants using models.

He told me that they have 9 (or so) simple models with which they can represent all plants.

The point being that nature uses very simple algorithms to create life.

Nature has optimised for the environment it exist in. That implies that these algorithms are optimised over eons.

It turns out that leafs on the trunk of a plant are distributed by the fibonacci sequence. Why is this? Because the distribution maximises the amount of sun each leaf gets when the plant does not know what the future will bring.

Fibonacci sequence is not perfect once the plant is larger but its the best approach when the plant does not know what the future brings --> [Phyllotaxis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phyllotaxis)

This made me think about living my life by the Fibonacci sequence somehow. The problem is how to do this. 

The idea would be to handle the unknown future. If plants use fibonacci, then it might also be applicable to us humans.

Interesting idea for influencing the unconsciousness.

name: Computers hinder social progress
info:
Computers hinder social progress by making inheritly outdated processes more efficient thus making their replacement unnecessary.

A completely different notion but one that has proven itself to be true. To the point of humans creating many workarounds to continue to support these outdated processes.

Another example would be voting in a democracy that continues to be done in an inefficient and wasteful manner - wasteful because it requires much paper for voting slips and inefficient since organising a vote takes much effort.

A more efficient method would be creating a system of voting that is purely digital and can be easily repeated as often as necessary. Thus allowing direct democracy to be implemented.
